metadata.source: Kāśinātha Śāstrī Āgāśe: Vācaspatimiśraviracitaṭīkāsaṃvalitavyāsabhāṣyasametāni Pātañjalayogasūtrāṇi, tathā bhojadevaviracitarājamārtaṇḍābhidhavṛttisametāni pātañjalayogasūtrāṇi. sūtrapāṭhasūtravarṇānukramasūcībhyāṃ ca sanāthīkṛtāni ...

body.translated_text: Now, the teaching of <s>Yoga</s> begins.
<s>Yoga</s> is the cessation of the fluctuations of the mind.
Then the seer abides in their own true form,
Otherwise, there is identification with the fluctuations.
The fluctuations are fivefold, afflicted or non-afflicted.
They are: correct perception, misconception, imagination, sleep, and memory.
Direct perception, inference, and testimony are the means of correct perception.
Misconception is false knowledge not based on the true form of its object.
Imagination is knowledge following words, devoid of an object.
Sleep is the fluctuation supported by the absence of content.
Memory is the non-loss of experienced objects.
Their cessation is through practice and <s>Vairāgya</s> (dispassion).
Effort towards steadiness is practice.
Indeed, it becomes firmly grounded by long duration, uninterrupted continuity, and sincere respect.
Dispassion is the mastery of one who is free from thirst for objects seen or heard about.
That is the highest, characterized by non-thirst for the <s>Guṇas</s> due to the realization of the <s>Puruṣa</s>.
With reasoning, reflection, bliss, and sense of 'I'-ness, follows <s>Samprajñāta</s>.
Another (state), preceded by practice, with the residual impressions remaining, is <s>Asamprajñāta</s>.
For those absorbed in the state of <s>Videha</s> or <s>Prakṛtilaya</s>, it is a cause of rebirth.
For others, it is preceded by faith, vigor, memory, <s>Samādhi</s>, and wisdom.
It is near for those with intense zeal.
Due to mild, medium, or intense nature, there is further distinction.
Or by devotion to <s>Īśvara</s>.
<s>Īśvara</s> is a special <s>Puruṣa</s>, untouched by afflictions, actions, results, and impressions.
In Him is the unsurpassed seed of omniscience.
He is the teacher even of the ancients, being unconditioned by time.
His expression is the <s>Praṇava</s> (Om).
Repetition of that (Om) and contemplation of its meaning.
From that arises the attainment of inner consciousness and the absence of obstacles.
Disease, dullness, doubt, carelessness, laziness, non-abstinence, misperception, non-attainment of a stage, instability, these are distractions of the mind, they are obstacles.
Pain, depression, tremor of the body, inhalation, and exhalation accompany the distractions.
For counteracting that, practice of one principle.
By cultivating friendliness, compassion, joy, and equanimity towards happiness, misery, virtue, and vice, the mind becomes serene.
Or by exhalation and retention of the <s>Prāṇa</s>.

body.text: viṣayavatī vā pravṛttir utpannā manasaḥ sthitinibandhanī || YS_1.35 ||
body.translated_text: Or the emergence of a perception filled with objects, binding the mind to steadiness.
Or the state of being luminous and free from sorrow.
Or the mind being free from attachment to objects.
Or support by the knowledge of dream and sleep.
Or by meditation as desired.
Mastery extends from the smallest to the greatest.

body.text: kṣīṇavṛtter abhijātasyeva maṇer grahītṛgrahaṇagrāhyeṣu tatsthatadañjanatā samāpattiḥ || YS_1.41 ||
body.translated_text: For the one whose fluctuations have diminished, like a transparent jewel, the identity with the knower, the process of knowing, and the object of knowledge is <s>Samāpatti</s>.

body.text: tatra śabdārthajñānavikalpaiḥ saṃkīrṇā savitarkā samāpattiḥ || YS_1.42 ||
body.translated_text: There, the <s>Samāpatti</s> mixed with verbal knowledge, meaning, and conceptualization is with reflection.
With the purification of memory, when the mind is devoid of its own form, only the object shines forth, without reflection.

body.text: etayaiva savicārā nirvicārā ca sūkṣmaviṣayā vyākhyātā || YS_1.44 ||
body.translated_text: By this, with reflection and without reflection, subtle objects are explained.
The subtle object culminates in the unmanifest.
These are the <s>Sabīja</s> (with seed) <s>Samādhi</s>.
Upon the clarity of non-reflective, there is the grace of the inner self.
There, the wisdom is truth-bearing.
It is different from knowledge gained through testimony or inference, because of its particular object.
The impression born from that is an obstacle to other impressions.

body.text: tasyāpi nirodhe sarvanirodhān nirbījaḥ samādhiḥ || YS_1.51 ||
body.translated_text: Upon its cessation, with the cessation of all, there is <s>Nirbīja</s> (seedless) <s>Samādhi</s>.
<s>Kriyā Yoga</s> consists of asceticism, self-study, and devotion to <s>Īśvara</s>.
For the cultivation of <s>Samādhi</s> and the attenuation of afflictions.
Ignorance, egoism, attachment, aversion, and clinging to life are the <s>kleśas</s> (afflictions),
Ignorance is the field for the others, whether dormant, attenuated, interrupted, or active.
Ignorance is perceiving the impermanent, impure, painful, and non-self as permanent, pure, pleasurable, and self.
Egoism is the identification of the power of the seer and the power of seeing as one.
Attachment is that which follows from pleasure.
Aversion is that which follows from pain.
Clinging to life is inherent, established even in the wise.
These subtle afflictions are to be overcome by reversal of the process of manifestation.
Their active states are to be overcome through meditation.
The repository of actions, rooted in afflictions, is experienced in visible and invisible births.
With the root existing, its fruition is birth, lifespan, and experiences.
They bring about pleasure or pain as fruits due to merit or demerit.

body.text: pariṇāmatāpasaṃskāraduḥkhair guṇavṛttivirodhāc ca duḥkham eva sarvaṃ vivekinaḥ || YS_2.15 ||
body.translated_text: To the discriminating, all is suffering due to the changes, anxieties, and impressions, as well as the opposition of the <s>Guṇas</s>.
The suffering that has not yet come is to be avoided.
The conjunction of the seer and the seen is the cause to be avoided.
The seen is of the nature of illumination, activity, and inertia, composed of elements and sense organs, for the purpose of experience and liberation.
The stages of the <s>Guṇas</s> are the specific, non-specific, indicator-only, and unmanifest.
The seer is pure consciousness, though witnessing thoughts.
The very essence of the seen exists for the sake of the seer.

body.text: kṛtārthaṃ prati naṣṭam apy anaṣṭaṃ tadanyasādhāraṇatvāt || YS_2.22 ||
body.translated_text: Though destroyed for the one who has achieved the purpose, it is not destroyed because it is common to others.
Conjunction is the cause of the realization of the nature of both the powers of the owner and the owned.
The cause of that is ignorance.

body.text: tadabhāvāt saṃyogābhāvo hānaṃ taddṛśeḥ kaivalyam || YS_2.25 ||
body.translated_text: In the absence of that, there is absence of conjunction, which is the liberation of the seer.
Unwavering discriminative knowledge is the means of liberation.
The culmination of that wisdom is in seven stages.

body.text: yogāṅgānuṣṭhānād aśuddhikṣaye jñānadīptir ā vivekakhyāteḥ || YS_2.28 ||
body.translated_text: From the practice of the limbs of <s>Yoga</s>, the destruction of impurities, and the light of knowledge, up to discriminative knowledge.
The eight limbs are restraint, observance, posture, breath control, withdrawal, concentration, meditation, and <s>Samādhi</s>.
Non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, celibacy, and non-possession are the restraints.
These are the great vows, universal, not limited by class, place, time, or circumstance.
Purity, contentment, asceticism, self-study, and devotion to <s>Īśvara</s> are the observances.
When disturbed by negative thoughts, cultivate the opposite.

body.text: vitarkā hiṃsādayaḥ kṛtakāritānumoditā lobhakrodhamohapūrvakā mṛdumadhyādhimātrā duḥkhājñānānantaphalā iti pratipakṣabhāvanam || YS_2.34 ||
body.translated_text: Negative thoughts like violence, whether done, caused, or approved, born of greed, anger, or delusion, mild, moderate, or intense, result in endless suffering and ignorance; thus, cultivate the opposite.
In the presence of one firmly established in non-violence, hostility is abandoned.
Upon the establishment of truthfulness, there is a grounding in the results of actions.
Upon the establishment of non-stealing, all jewels present themselves.
Upon the establishment of celibacy, there is the acquisition of vigor.
Upon the establishment of non-possession, there comes knowledge of the how and why of existence.
From purity, there arises distaste for one's own body and non-contact with others.
Purity also leads to clarity of mind, cheerfulness, concentration, mastery of senses, and fitness for self-realization.
From contentment, there is the attainment of unsurpassed happiness.
From asceticism, the destruction of impurities and the perfection of the body and senses.
From self-study, there is union with the desired deity.
From devotion to <s>Īśvara</s>, the attainment of <s>Samādhi</s>.
Posture should be steady and comfortable.
By relaxation of effort and merging with the infinite.
From that, one is not afflicted by the dualities.

body.text: tasmin sati śvāsapraśvāsayor gativicchedaḥ prāṇāyāmaḥ || YS_2.49 ||
body.translated_text: When that is achieved, the cessation of the movement of inhalation and exhalation is <s>Prāṇāyāma</s>.
The external, internal, and stilled motions are observed in terms of place, time, and number, becoming prolonged and subtle.
The fourth is that which transcends the external and internal.
From that, the covering of illumination is weakened.
And the mind becomes fit for concentration.
Withdrawal is as if the senses imitate the nature of the mind in its non-contact with objects.
From that, there is supreme mastery over the senses.
Concentration is the binding of the mind to a place.
There, the flow of the mind towards one object is <s>Dhyāna</s> (meditation)

body.text: tad evārthamātranirbhāsaṃ svarūpaśūnyam iva samādhiḥ || YS_3.3 ||
body.translated_text: That, when shining forth with only the object, as if devoid of its own form, is <s>Samādhi</s>
These three together are <s>Saṃyama</s>
From mastery of that, comes the light of knowledge
Its application is in stages
These three are more internal than the previous ones
Even these are external to <s>Nirbīja</s> (seedless) <s>Samādhi</s>
The suppression and emergence of the impressions of emergence and suppression, and the continuity of the moment of suppression with the mind, is the transformation of suppression
From that, the flow of tranquility is due to the impression
The diminution and rise of all-pointedness and one-pointedness of the mind is the transformation of <s>Samādhi</s>

body.text: tataḥ punaḥ śāntoditau tulyapratyayau cittasyaikāgratāpariṇāmaḥ || YS_3.12 ||
body.translated_text: Then again, the tranquil and the arisen, with equal thoughts, is the transformation of one-pointedness of the mind
By this, the transformations of characteristics, signs, and states in the elements and senses are explained
The substratum follows the tranquil, arisen, and undistinguished characteristics
The difference in sequence is the cause of difference in transformation
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the three transformations, knowledge of past and future

body.text: śabdārthapratyayānām itaretarādhyāsāt saṃkaras tatpravibhāgasaṃyamāt sarvabhūtarutajñānam || YS_3.17 ||
body.translated_text: By the superimposition of sound, meaning, and idea, there is confusion; by <s>Saṃyama</s> on their distinction, knowledge of all beings' sounds
From direct perception of impressions, knowledge of previous births
Through the idea, knowledge of others' minds

body.text: na ca tat sālambanaṃ tasyāviṣayībhūtatvāt || YS_3.20 ||
body.translated_text: But that is not with support, because it is not an object
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the form of the body, when the power of perception is restrained, there is invisibility

body.text: sopakramaṃ nirupakramaṃ ca karma tatsaṃyamād aparāntajñānam ariṣṭebhyo vā || YS_3.22 ||
body.translated_text: From <s>Saṃyama</s> on actions with immediate and future results, knowledge of death, or from signs
Strengths in friendliness and the like
Among strengths, the strength of an elephant and so forth
By placing the light of activity, knowledge of the subtle, hidden, and distant
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the sun, knowledge of the worlds
On the moon, knowledge of the arrangement of stars
On the pole star, knowledge of their motion
On the navel wheel, knowledge of the body's structure
In the throat pit, cessation of hunger and thirst
In the <s>Kūrma Nāḍī</s>, steadiness
In the light of the head, vision of the accomplished ones
Or through intuition, everything
In the heart, knowledge of the mind

body.text: sattvapuruṣayor atyantāsaṃkīrṇayoḥ pratyayāviśeṣo bhogaḥ parārthāt svārthasaṃyamāt puruṣajñānam || YS_3.35 ||
body.translated_text: From <s>Saṃyama</s> on the purpose of the self, knowledge of the <s>Puruṣa</s>, which is distinct from the <s>Sattva</s>, due to the lack of intermingling
From that arise intuitive hearing, touch, vision, taste, and smell

body.text: te samādhāv upasargā vyutthāne siddhayaḥ || YS_3.37 ||
body.translated_text: They are obstacles in <s>Samādhi</s>, but perfections in the active state

body.text: bandhakāraṇaśaithilyāt pracārasaṃvedanāc ca cittasya paraśarīrāveśaḥ || YS_3.38 ||
body.translated_text: By loosening the cause of bondage and knowledge of the movement, the mind enters another's body

body.text: udānajayāj jalapaṅkakaṇṭakādiṣv asaṅga utkrāntiś ca || YS_3.39 ||
body.translated_text: Through mastery of <s>Udāna</s>, non-contact with water, mud, thorns, etc., and the power of ascent
Through mastery of <s>Samāna</s>, there is radiance
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the relationship between ear and space, divine hearing
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the relationship between body and space, and the lightness of cotton, movement through space

body.text: bahir akalpitā vṛttir mahāvidehā tataḥ prakāśāvaraṇakṣayaḥ || YS_3.43 ||
body.translated_text: The external, non-conceptual state is the great disembodiment, from that, the covering of illumination is destroyed
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the gross, essential, subtle, conjunction, and purpose, mastery over the elements
From that, the emergence of <s>Aṇimā</s> and other powers, perfection of the body, and non-obstruction of its functions
Perfection of the body includes beauty, grace, strength, and diamond-like firmness
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the grasping, form, sense of 'I'-ness, conjunction, and purpose, mastery over the senses

body.text: tato manojavitvaṃ vikaraṇabhāvaḥ pradhānajayaś ca || YS_3.48 ||
body.translated_text: From that, the speed of mind, non-instrumentality, and mastery over <s>Pradhāna</s>
For one who has realized the distinction between <s>Sattva</s> and <s>Puruṣa</s>, there is the mastery over all states and omniscience
From dispassion towards that, with the destruction of the seeds of defects, there is liberation
When invited by the inhabitants of higher realms, there should be no attachment or pride, due to the possibility of undesirable consequences
Through <s>Saṃyama</s> on the moment and its sequence, knowledge born of discrimination

body.text: jātilakṣaṇadeśair anyatānavacchedāt tulyayos tataḥ pratipattiḥ || YS_3.53 ||
body.translated_text: Due to the unbroken continuity of differences in species, characteristics, and locations, there is understanding of what is alike and what is distinct.

body.text: tārakaṃ sarvaviṣayaṃ sarvathāviṣayam akramaṃ ceti vivekajaṃ jñānam || YS_3.54 ||
body.translated_text: Knowledge born of discrimination is illuminating, encompassing all objects, beyond all objects, and without sequence.
When there is equality of purity between <s>Sattva</s> and <s>Puruṣa</s>, it is liberation.
Perfections are born from birth, herbs, mantras, austerity, and <s>Samādhi</s>.
Transformation into another species is due to the overflow of <s>Prakṛti</s>.

body.text: nimittam aprayojakaṃ prakṛtīnāṃ varaṇabhedas tu tataḥ kṣetrikavat || YS_4.3 ||
body.translated_text: The cause is not the initiator of the transformation of <s>Prakṛtis</s>, but the removal of obstacles, like a farmer.
Constructed minds arise from egoism alone.

body.text: pravṛttibhede prayojakaṃ cittam ekam anekeṣām || YS_4.5 ||
body.translated_text: In the diversity of activities, one mind is the initiator among many.
There, the one born of meditation is devoid of residual impressions.
For a <s>Yogi</s>, actions are neither white nor black; for others, they are threefold.
Then, there is the manifestation of subliminal impressions corresponding to their fruition.

body.text: jātideśakālavyavahitānām apy ānantaryaṃ smṛtisaṃskārayor ekarūpatvāt || YS_4.9 ||
body.translated_text: Even when separated by species, place, and time, there is continuity due to the uniformity of memory and impression.
Their beginninglessness is due to the eternality of desire.

body.text: hetuphalāśrayālambanaiḥ saṃgṛhītatvād eṣām abhāve tadabhāvaḥ || YS_4.11 ||
body.translated_text: Because they are held together by cause, effect, support, and object, in their absence, there is the absence of that.
The past and future exist in their own form due to the difference in the path of properties.
They are manifest and subtle, having the nature of <s>Guṇas</s>.
Due to the oneness of transformation, the reality of the object is established.

body.text: vastusāmye cittabhedāt tayor vibhaktaḥ panthāḥ || YS_4.15 ||
body.translated_text: Though the object is the same, due to the difference in minds, their paths are distinct.

body.text: na caikacittatantraṃ vastu tadapramāṇakaṃ tadā kiṃ syāt || YS_4.16 ||
body.translated_text: The object is not dependent on one mind, otherwise, when not cognized, what would it be?
An object is known or unknown depending on whether the mind is colored by it.

body.text: sadā jñātāś cittavṛttayas tatprabhoḥ puruṣasyāpariṇāmitvāt || YS_4.18 ||
body.translated_text: The fluctuations of the mind are always known to the lord, the <s>Puruṣa</s>, due to its unchanging nature.
It does not illuminate itself, because it is an object of perception.
Both cannot be determined at the same time.

body.text: cittāntaradṛśye buddhibuddher atiprasaṅgaḥ smṛtisaṃkaraś ca || YS_4.21 ||
body.translated_text: If one mind were to perceive another, there would be an over-extension of cognition and confusion of memory.
Due to the non-transference of consciousness, when assuming that form, there is self-awareness of one's own cognition.
The mind, colored by the seer and the seen, is for all purposes.

body.text: tad asaṃkhyeyavāsanābhiś citram api parārthaṃ saṃhatyakāritvāt || YS_4.24 ||
body.translated_text: Though diverse due to innumerable impressions, it is for another's purpose, because it acts in conjunction.
For one who sees the distinction, there is cessation of the contemplation of one's own being.
Then, the mind inclined towards discrimination leans towards liberation.
In the gaps of that, other thoughts arise from impressions.
Their removal is said to be like the afflictions.

body.text: prasaṃkhyāne 'py akusīdasya sarvathā vivekakhyāter dharmameghaḥ samādhiḥ || YS_4.29 ||
body.translated_text: For one who is not attached even in the highest knowledge, from discriminative knowledge, there is the <s>Dharma Megha</s> <s>Samādhi</s>.
From that, there is cessation of afflictions and actions.

body.text: tadā sarvāvaraṇamalāpetasya jñānasyānantyāj jñeyam alpam || YS_4.31 ||
body.translated_text: Then, for one whose knowledge is infinite, with all coverings and impurities removed, the knowable is little.
Then, for those who have achieved their purpose, the sequence of transformation of the <s>Guṇas</s> comes to an end.
The sequence is grasped as the counterpart of the moment and the endpoint of transformation.

body.text: puruṣārthaśūnyānāṃ guṇānāṃ pratiprasavaḥ kaivalyaṃ svarūpapratiṣṭhā vā citiśaktir iti || YS_4.34 ||
body.translated_text: The reabsorption of the <s>Guṇas</s> that have no purpose for the <s>Puruṣa</s> is liberation, or the establishment in one's own form, which is the power of consciousness.
